block.p: Philippine troops killed 12 and wounded at least 94 when they fired into a crowd of demonstrators in Manila. It was the first time troops had fired on demonstrators since Corazon Aquino came to power.

Iran reported 800 civilian casualties in 10 Iranian cities as the air war between Iran and Iraq appeared to escalate. Air raid warnings have become common occurrences in Teheran, where life still bustles.
George P. Shultz is not a team player and is trying to shirk responsibility for the Iran arms deal, some White House officials said.

George W. Cave met with negotiators from Iran on behalf of the C.I.A., Congressional and other sources said. He is a former agent who has figured in most of the secret dealings between the two countries.
The President's public statements about Iran last November and December differed fundamentally from events occurring at about the same time, a review of those statements shows.
A New York City lawyer will serve as chief counsel of the Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair. Arthur L. Liman, a criminal-law specialist, has directed several government inquiries.
The U.S. asked Singapore to provide communications equipment to the Nicaraguan rebels, officials said. Singapore said it did not manufacture the equipment. The U.S. also asked Brunei for money.
Talks to end the Afghanistan war have been scheduled in the Soviet Union, Pakistani officials said. They said the Pakistani Foreign Minister will soon go to Moscow for another round of meetings.
An eruption of carbon dioxide gas killed more than 1,800 people near Lake Nios in Cameroon last August, scientists generally agree. But they differ on what caused the eruption.

A power struggle among the contras is splitting the Nicaraguan guerrilla movement and threatening the rebel leadership just as they are trying to launch a new offensive, American and rebel officials said.
A sex-offense case in London, involving a British child and the husband of an American diplomat formerly based there, came to light this week and immediately attracted national attention.

Japan received no promise from Treasury Secretary Baker for help in coping with the falling dollar. Mr. Baker showed more clearly his strategy to force allies to run their economies his way, analysts said. .
Les Aspin will again head the House Armed Services Committee. The Wisconsin Democrat staged a comeback after fellow Democrats voted two weeks ago against retaining him as chairman.
NASA has failed to draw on expertise other than Morton Thiokol's to redesign the shuttle booster rockets and appears ''locked in'' a close relationship with the company, Senate members said.
A Pennsylvania official shot himself to death at a news conference in the state capital. Treasurer R. Budd Dwyer, convicted last month of bribery, said he was innocent, then drew his gun.
Klan members from 20 states may march in Forsyth County, Ga., Saturday in a counterdemonstration against a planned ''march against fear and intimidation,'' two Klansmen said.
Star Wars should be deployed soon because the chance to stay ahead of Soviet technology ''will not remain with us forever,'' Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said at a space symposium.

The State of the Union Message by President Reagan will address the Iran issue and will be the most important speech of his Presidency, Mr. Reagan's poll-taker Richard Wirthlin told a group of reporters.
An article attacking Miranda, the Supreme Court's ruling that the police inform suspects of their rights, has been prepared by the Atttorney General for a law review, the Justice Department said.
The Dow Jones scored a record rise yesterday, gaining 51.60 points. The industrial average closed at 2,145.67, one day after suffering its first setback of 1987.
Drug test snag in train wreck
All eyes on Wright and his brows Regional
The winter's first major snowstorm roared up the Eastern Seaboard and across the New York metropolitan region yesterday, disrupting transportation, commerce, education, and government services.
L.I.R.R. and the supervisors' union reached agreement yesterday, but the prospect for a quick end to the five-day-old walkout appeared unlikely. Nine unions are still without agreements.

Carl Capasso pleaded guilty to tax-evasion charges yesterday at his arraignment. A contractor who has done major work for New York City, Mr. Capasso denied any corruption and defended his friend, Bess Myerson.
3 centers advising against abortions may have engaged in deceptive advertising, women who visited the centers contend. The State Attorney General's office is investigating the charges.
Gov. Cuomo's five candidates for seats on the state Public Service Commission met with resistance from the State Senate, which must confirm them. The Governor announced the nominations yesterday.
The 33d Winter Antiques Show opens tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan. The show features furniture, ceramic figures, bronzes, wood carvings, sculptures, paintings, and stitchery.
City examines death of 2 babies in foster homes
